block.p: Sharon Opens Campaign; U.S. Envoy Delays Trip Ariel Sharon, the hawkish Likud Party leader and clear front-runner for the premiership of Israel, formally kicked off his campaign, as an American envoy, Dennis Ross, indefinitely postponed a trip to the region for last-minute peacemaking efforts.

Long-Lost Pilot Now 'Missing' The Navy has decided to change the status of an American fighter pilot shot down over Iraq during the Persian Gulf war in 1991 to ''missing in action,'' nearly a decade after he was declared dead, officials said. New evidence suggests that Lt. Cmdr. Michael Scott Speicher survived the crash in western Iraq, though there is no indication he is still alive.

Report on Moscow Sales to Iran A bipartisan American panel said Russian sales to Iran of technology that has both civilian and military uses are a major obstacle to expanding American efforts to prevent the spread of Russian nuclear material and remain problematic in relations between Washington and Moscow.
No Ban on NATO Uranium Arms A majority of NATO countries rejected requests from several allies for a temporary ban on the inclusion of depleted-uranium munitions in NATO arsenals.

Bosnian Serb to Face Charges Biljana Plavsic, the former president of the Bosnian Serb republic, surrendered in The Hague to face charges of genocide and other war crimes committed primarily against Muslims in Bosnia in 1991 and 1992.

German Action on Beef Scare Chancellor Gerhard Schroder created a superministry for food, agriculture and consumer protection and gave it to the environmentalist Green Party. The move signals an approach to fighting mad cow disease certain to alarm the powerful European farm lobby.

All G.O.P. Senators Back Ashcroft, Lott Declares The Republicans' Senate leader, Trent Lott, said all 50 Republican votes were behind President-elect George W. Bush's choice for attorney general, John Ashcroft, and Mr. Lott warned that Democratic efforts to derail the nomination could poison efforts to set a new cooperative tone on Capitol Hill. Conservative groups vowed to mount a grass-roots effort to build support for Mr. Ashcroft.

Linda Chavez said a lack of vocal support from Mr. Bush and his team had persuaded her to withdraw her name from consideration as labor secretary in a furor over her having taken in an illegal immigrant.

Mr. Bush's choice for secretary of education, Roderick R. Paige, told a Senate committee that he supported using taxpayer money to send children to private schools under some conditions. Although some Democrats opposed that stance, they said his confirmation was expected.
Mr. Bush had a top-secret Pentagon session with the Joint Chiefs of Staff to review hot spots in the world.

Reserves to Join Nuclear Force The Pentagon will open strategic nuclear forces to members of the National Guard and Reserves, helping the military fill sometimes hard-to-fill vacancies among the forces that control nuclear weapons.

Judge Faults Financing Formula A New York State judge declared the state's method of financing public schools illegal, saying it deprives New York City students of the ''sound, basic education'' guaranteed by the State Constitution.
Teacher Views on Standards Most American teachers say that the movement to set educational standards has made gains but that achievement tests are poorly written and dominate classroom life.

Con Ed Report Says Plant Was Restarted Too Quickly An internal report by Con Edison said the utility might have felt pressured to reopen the Indian Point 2 nuclear plant after 10 months of repairs, and so moved too fast last week, putting the reactor into a condition that is harder to monitor and control and delaying its return to full power.

Unsatisfactory Jail Conditions A federal judge, acting on a city request to end two decades of court monitoring of city jails, ruled that several shortcomings persist, including foul air and very cold and unsanitary conditions in some jails.

Tiny Relic of Ancient Earth Scientists say a grain-sized crystal from western Australia is the oldest piece of Earth yet identified and may lead to a rethinking of theories on when life appeared on the planet, as well as the origin of the Moon.

New Factor in Climate Change Droughts caused by global warming could set off a biochemical process in northern soils that would release large amounts of carbon dioxide into the air and possibly speed up climate changes, researchers say.

Product of a Stellar Explosion Astronomers using the orbiting Chandra X-Ray Observatory found evidence that an object known as a pulsar was created in the spectacular explosion of a massive star that the Chinese recorded in A.D. 386.
Airlines Explain Plan American Airlines and United Airlines disclosed details of their five-airline, multibillion-dollar blueprint for remaking the industry.
Battery Maker Expects Trouble Exide said federal prosecutors were likely to seek an indictment or a plea bargain arising from an inquiry into its relationship with Sears.
Editorials: A landmark school ruling; America's biggest airlines head east; not really tempted.
